arguments.claim: The High Court was not competent to grant certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) or (b) because the Division Bench judgment affirms the decision of the District Judge (court immediately below), and no substantial question of law is involved.

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney-General, however, contended that the judgment of the High Court against which this appeal is preferred affirms the decision of the court immediately below and the appeal does not involve any substantial question of law and therefore the High Court was not competent to grant the certificate under Art.133 (1) (a) (b).

holdings.text: The appeal with certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133(1)(a) and (b) is competent, because a Single Judge of the High Court hearing either a proceeding as a Court of original jurisdiction or in exercise of appellate jurisdiction is a Court immediately below the Division Bench which hears an appeal against his judgment under the relevant clause of the Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appeal with certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133  1   a  and  b  is competent, because a Single Judge of the High Court hearing either a proceeding as a Court of original jurisdiction or in exercise of appellate jurisdiction is a Court immediately below the Division Bench which hears an appeal against his judgment under the relevant clause of the Letters Patent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes 'court immediately below' from 'subordinate court'; Letters Patent appeal treats single judge as immediately below Division Bench; consistent practice and precedents from Privy Council, other HCs; rejects respondent's domestic appeal argument.

holdings.text: Bishan Narain J. did not transgress s.100 CPC restrictions in reversing District Judge, as decision involved substantial procedural errors, lack of evidence, wrong burden of proof on undue influence plea.

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Narain J., was, it is true, hearing an appeal from an appellate decree and his powers were restricted, for a second appeal lies to the High Court only on the following grounds, namely- ... A decision of the first appellate Court reached after placing the onus wrongly or based on no evidence, or where there has been substantial error or defect in the procedure, producing error or defect -in the decision of the case on the merits, is not conclusive and a second appeal lies to the High Court against that decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undue influence finding not pure fact but involved procedural defects (O6R4 particulars lacking, no evidence, wrong onus), allowing interference under s.100 CPC grounds (a),(b),(c).

holdings.text: Plea of undue influence lacks sufficient particulars as required by O.6 R.4 CPC; vague plea without precise nature, manner of influence, unfair advantage.

anchor.surface_text: o. 6 r. 4 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that in all cases in which the party pleading relies on any misrepresentation, fraud, breach of trust, wilful default, or undue influence... A plea of undue influence must, to serve that dual purpose, be precise and all necessary particulars in support of the plea must be embodied in the pleading.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule requires dates/items for fraud/undue influence pleas to narrow issues, prevent surprise; defendants' plea vague (dictatorial powers, point of dagger metaphorically, financial pressure unspecified); no amendment despite opportunities; Privy Council and SC precedents mandate specifics.

holdings.text: Resolutions dated October 16, 1945 not vitiated by undue influence or coercion; plea not substantiated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No particulars/evidence of dominance or unfair use; defendants led no evidence despite burden/opportunities; acquiesced/acted upon resolutions; contradicted by prior revolt/removal as MD.

holdings.text: No presumption under Section 16(3) Indian Contract Act; plaintiff not in position to dominate will of defendants, transaction not unconscionable.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Indian Contract Act... where a person who is in a position to dominate the will of another... the burden of proving that such contract was not induced by undue influence shall lie upon the person... But sub-section (3) has manifestly a limited application the presumption will only arise if it is established by evidence that the party who had obtained the benefit of a transaction was in a position to dominate the will of the other and that the transaction is shown to be unconscionable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s16(3) requires proof of dominance position (no real/apparent authority, no fiduciary post-1940 separation/1945 removal) AND unconscionable transaction (shares/remuneration equalized, benefits mutual; accounts scrutinized per evidence).

holdings.text: Resolutions passed at Directors meeting March 3, 1946 and extraordinary general meeting March 28, 1946 invalid and not binding on plaintiff due to lack of notice breaching Oct 16 resolutions/Articles requiring unanimity/quorum.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No notice to Ladli Prasad; breaches unanimity requirement, natural justice; all lower courts concurred.

holdings.text: Plaintiff entitled to declaration that March 1946 resolutions invalid and permanent injunction restraining defendants from acting upon them, subject to proviso not affecting third party rights/liabilities unless adversely affecting plaintiff/Company.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to enter upon a discussion of the question whether in the circumstances it was a sufficient ground for depriving the plaintiff of relief, for we are of opinion that subject to the reservations made by Bishan Narain, J., which fully protect third parties, relief should be awarded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No undue influence so no unclean hands; all courts agree on invalidity; proviso/undertaking protects third parties; counters delay/lien arguments.

precedents.citation: Tulsi Prasad v. Benayak R. 23 I. A. 102

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney- General, however, concedes and in our judgment properly that there has been a long standing practice which has the approval of the Privy Council see Tulsi Prasad v. Benayak R. 23 I. A. 102 that if the decree or order of the Division Bench reverses the judgment of a single

precedents.cited_proposition: long standing practice approved by Privy Council that appeal lies as matter of course if Division Bench reverses single judge in original jurisdiction without needing substantial question of law

precedents.citation: Wahid-ud-din v. Makhan Lal 1 1944 I.L.R. 26 Lah. 24

anchor.surface_text: In Wahid-ud-din v. Makhan Lal 1 a full Bench of the Lahore High Court Blacker, J., dissenting , held that for the purposes of s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908 which is in material terms identical with Art. 133 of the Constitution a judge of a High Court sitting to hear number an original proceeding, but as a companyrt of appeal cannot be companysidered a companyrt immediately below the Bench hearing the Letters Patent appeal from his judgment, 1 1944 I.L.R. 26 Lah. 24.

precedents.cited_proposition: a single judge of High Court exercising appellate jurisdiction is not court immediately below Division Bench for s.110 CPC / Art.133 purposes
precedents.cited_holding: judge sitting on appellate side is the High Court itself, not court immediately below

precedents.citation: Debendra Nath Das v. Bibudhendra Mansingh 1 1915 I.L.R, 43 Cal. 90

anchor.surface_text: There is a decision of the Calcutta High Court in Debendra Nath Das v. Bibudhendra Mansingh 1 , decided by Jenkins, C. J., and N. R. Chatterjee, J., which has expressed a similar view. The learned Chief justice in delivering the judgment of the Court observed at p. 93 It only remains to be seen whether as regards nature the requirements of section I I 0 are fulfilled. 1 1915 I.L.R, 43 Cal. 90.

precedents.case_name: Debendra Nath Das v. Bibudhendra Mansingh
precedents.cited_proposition: judgment of single judge in appellate jurisdiction not considered for affirming decision of court immediately below
precedents.cited_holding: effective judgment of High Court affirmed lower court despite intermediate reversal by single judge

precedents.citation: Minna Heatherly B. C. Sen 1 A.I.R. 1927 Lah. 537

anchor.surface_text: There are however two earlier judgments of the Lahore High Court which have expressed a companytrary view. Minna Heatherly B. C. Sen 1 and Gopal Lal v. Balkissan 2 . In these two cases it was held that a Single judge of the High Court hearing an appeal is within the meaning of s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908 a companyrt immediately below the Division Bench of the High Court hearing an appeal under the Letters Patent. 1 A.I.R. 1927 Lah. 537.

precedents.case_name: Minna Heatherly v. B. C. Sen
precedents.cited_proposition: single judge hearing appeal is court immediately below Division Bench under s.110 CPC

precedents.citation: Gopal Lal v. Balkissan 2 1931 I.L.R. 13 Lah. 318

anchor.surface_text: Minna Heatherly B. C. Sen 1 and Gopal Lal v. Balkissan 2 . In these two cases it was held that a Single judge of the High Court hearing an appeal is within the meaning of s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908 a companyrt immediately below the Division Bench of the High Court hearing an appeal under the Letters Patent. The High Court of Nagpur in Kishanlal Nandlal v. Vithal Nagayya, 3 , has preferred the earlier view of the Lahore High Court. 2 1931 I.L.R. 13 Lah. 318.

precedents.cited_proposition: single judge hearing appeal is court immediately below Division Bench under s.110 CPC

precedents.citation: Kishanlal Nandlal v. Vithal Nagayya I.L.R. 1955 Nag. 821

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Nagpur in Kishanlal Nandlal v. Vithal Nagayya, 3 , has preferred the earlier view of the Lahore High Court. In our judgment the appeal with certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1 a and b is companypetent, because a Single Judge of the High Court hearing either a proceeding as a Court of original jurisdiction or in exercise of appellate jurisdiction is a Court immediately below the Division Bench which hears an appeal against his judgment under the relevant clause of the Letters Patent. 3 I.L.R. 1955 Nag. 821.

precedents.cited_proposition: preferred view that single judge appellate is court immediately below

precedents.citation: Satgur Prasad v. Har Narain Das 1 1932 L.R. 59 I.A. 147

anchor.surface_text: Whether a particular transaction was vitiated on the ground of undue influence is primarily a decision on a question of fact. In Satgur Prasad v. Har Narain Das 1 , the Privy Council held that in a suit to set aside a deed on the ground that it was procured by undue influence and fraud, the finding that it was so procured is a finding of fact and is number liable to be re-opened if fairly tried. 1 1932 L.R. 59 I.A. 147.

precedents.case_name: Satgur Prasad v. Har Narain Das
precedents.cited_proposition: finding that deed procured by undue influence is finding of fact not liable to be reopened in second appeal if fairly tried
precedents.cited_holding: finding of undue influence is question of fact

precedents.citation: Mussummant Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri 2 1890 L.R. 17 I.A. 122

anchor.surface_text: Under the Civil Procedure Code, a second appeal does number lie to the High Court, except on the grounds- specified in the relevant provision of the Code, prescribing the right to prefer a second appeal,and the High Court has numberjurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of an erroneous finding of fact however gross or inexcusable the error may seem to be Mussummant Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri 2 . 2 1890 L.R. 17 I.A. 122.

precedents.case_name: Mussummant Durga Choudhrain v. Jawahir Singh Choudhri
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court has no jurisdiction in second appeal on erroneous finding of fact however gross

precedents.citation: Bharat Dharma Syndicate v. Harish Chandra 1 1917 64 I.A. 146

anchor.surface_text: In Bharat Dharma Syndicate v. Harish Chandra 1 , the Privy Council emphasized the necessity of particulars in the following terms Their Lordships desire to call attention to the great difficulty which is occasioned both to persons charged with fraud or other improper companyduct, and to the tribunal which are called upon to decide such issues, if the litigant who prefers the charges is number companypelled to place on record precise and specific details of those charges. 1 1917 64 I.A. 146.

precedents.case_name: Bharat Dharma Syndicate v. Harish Chandra
precedents.cited_proposition: necessity of precise and specific particulars of fraud or undue influence in pleadings
precedents.cited_holding: must amend petition to include full particulars of allegations

precedents.citation: Bishnudeo Narain v. Seogeni Rai and Jagernath 2 1951 S.C.R. 548

anchor.surface_text: Similarly this Court in Bishnudeo Narain v. Seogeni Rai and Jagernath 2 , in dealing with the practice to be followed in a case where a plea of undue influence and companyrcion is raised, observed at p. 656 It is also to be observed that numberproper particulars have been furnished. Now if there is one rule which is better established than any other, it is that in cases of fraud, undue influence and companyrcion, the parties pleading it must set forth full particulars and the case can only be decided on the particulars as laid. 2 1951 S.C.R. 548.

precedents.case_name: Bishnudeo Narain v. Seogeni Rai and Jagernath
precedents.cited_proposition: in undue influence cases, must set forth full particulars; case decided on pleaded particulars only
precedents.cited_holding: general allegations insufficient even if strong language
